questions.text: Which of the following methods is routinely used for the isolation of the bacteria?
questions.solution:
The method used for the isolation of the bacteria is streak culture.

Streak culture is routinely used for the isolation of bacteria in pure culture from clinical specimens. It is prepared by picking the specimen using platinum loops or straight wires and transferring it onto a well-dried plate. The inoculum is then distributed thinly over the plate by streaking it with the loop in a series of parallel lines in different segments of the plate. 

Other methods used in bacterial culture:

Lawn culture/carpet culture: It is used for bacteriophage typing and antibiotic sensitivity testing. It is prepared by flooding the surface of the plate with a liquid culture.

Stab culture is prepared by puncturing a suitable medium with a long, straight, charged wire. The oxygen-requiring bacteria will grow on the surface, and the bacteria that do not require oxygen will grow at the bottom.

Stroke culture: It provides pure growth of bacterium for slide agglutination and other diagnostic tests.

Pour plate culture: It gives an estimate of viable bacterial count in a suspension. It is prepared by adding appropriate dilutions of the inoculum (1 ml) to the molten (40-45°C) agar, which is mixed and poured into sterile Petri dishes. After incubation, colonies are seen to be distributed throughout the depth of the medium. 

Liquid culture: These are preferred for inocula containing antibiotics and other inhibitory substances. It is prepared by inoculating liquid cultures in tubes, bottles, or flasks by touching them with a charged loop, pipettes, or syringes.

questions.text: The characteristic appearance on nutrient agar as shown in the image below is formed by _____
questions.solution:
• The above image shows characteristic “Oil paint appeareance” with golden yellow colour pigment formed by Staphylococcus aureus.
  • On nutrient agar, after 24 hours of incubation the Staphylococcus colonies are large, circular, convex, smooth, shiny, opaque and easily emulsifiable.
  • Most strains produce golden yellow pigment, some may be white, orange or yellow. Pigment production occurs optimally at 22°C and only in aerobic cultures.
  • Golden yellow pigmentation on nutrient agar is due to β-carotene.
  • On nutrient agar slope, the confluent growth presents a characteristic “oil-paint appearance”. In liquid media, uniform turbidity is produced.
  • Pigment production is enhanced when 1% glycerol or when milk is incorporated in the medium.

The table below shows appearance of Staphylococcus Aureus growth in Various Culture Media:

Culture Medium Appeareance
Nutrient Agar Oil paint Appeareance
Blood Agar Most Strains are haemolytic
Mac Conkey’s medium Small colonies that are pink due to lactose fermentation
Phenolphthalein phosphate agar bright pink colonies
Mannitol Salt Agar colonies surrounded by yellow zones
K tellurite agar Black Colonies

questions.text: MHC molecules have promiscuous binding specificity. This implies that

choices.text: A particular MHC molecule has the potential to bind to different peptides
When MHC molecules bind to peptides, they are degraded
Peptides bind with low affinity to MHC molecules
None of the above describes promiscuous binding specificity

questions.solution:
• A particular MHC molecule has the potential to bind to different peptides
  • MHC class I and II molecules are glycoproteins which present peptides to the T cells. Each MHC molecule has only one binding site. Many different peptides can bind to the same MHC molecule. This type of binding is termed as promiscuous binding.
  • Each class I or II molecule will bind only to certain peptides and will have a set of criteria that a peptide must have in order to bind to binding site.
  • A few residues in the peptide, called anchor residues, bind to specific pockets on the MHC-I, resulting in some specificity of interactions with MHC.
  • Thus, many different peptides can bind to a single MHC, however, some peptides can bind to more than one MHC.

The following table shows the differentiating characteristics of MHC Class I and MHC Class II antigens.

MHC Class I MHC Class II
Present on all nucleated cells ( except sperms) and platelets Present on antigen presenting cells
Presents endogenous peptide antigen to  CD8+ T cells Presents Exogenous antigen to CD4+ T cells
Presents antigen via Cytosolic pathway Presents antigen via Endocytic pathway
Peptide binds to α1/α2 groove Peptide binds to α1/β1 groove
α3 binds to CD8 molecules on cytotoxic T cells  β2 binds to CD4 on Helper T cells

questions.text: All of the following play a role in the virulence of Vibrio cholera except
questions.solution:
• Though Vibrio cholera is a gram negative bacillus possessing Lipopolysaccharide (LPS) O antigen, it apparently plays no role in the pathogenesis of Cholera but is responsible for the immunity induced by killed vaccines.
  • Vibrio cholerae is a highly motile bacterium which possesses a single polar flagellum as a locomotion organelle. Motility is thought to be an important factor for the virulence of V. cholerae.
  • Special fimbriae present on Vibrio cholerae, known as “Toxin co-regulated Pilus” (TCP) is essential for the adhesion to the epithelial surface and colonization of the bacteria in small intestine.
  • Cholera Toxin (also known as Choleragen, cholera enterotoxin) plays an important role in causing watery diarrhoea through cAMP mediated pathway.

questions.text: A junior doctor sustained a needle-stick injury while sampling the blood of a patient who is HIV positive. A decision is taken to offer him post-exposure prophylaxis. Which one of the following regimen would be the best recommendation?
questions.solution:
Recommended Post-exposure prophylaxis(PEP) is a three drug regimen which includes Lamivudine 300mg , Tenofovir 300mg and Dolutegravir 50mg. A regimen for post - exposure prophylaxis for HIV with two ARV drugs is effective, but three drugs are preferred. The PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours. WHO recommended PEP regimen :

        Drugs combination   Recommendation for PEP         Duration
Tenofovir (TDF) 300 mg + Lamivudine(3TC) 300 mg + Dolutegravir (DTG) 50mg          Once daily          4 weeks

DTG is recommended as the preferred third drug for HIV post-exposure prophylaxis. When available, ATV/r, DRV/r, LPV/r and RAL may be considered as alternative third drug options for post-exposure prophylaxis

The protocol followed is :Exposure within 72 hours --> Assess exposed individual --> Assess exposure source --> Determine the risk of transmission --> Counselling and support --> 28 - day prescription with drug information --> HIV test at 3 months after exposure.

Note: The NACO October 2018 guidelines recommend the two drug regimen but the recent MOHFW JAN 2020 recommends the three drug regimen as per WHO December 2018 guidelines as the preferred treatment for PEP in HIV.

Related Pearl: 2021 NACO Guidelines on Post-exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) for HIV

Exposure Code

HIV Source Code

          PEP Recommendation

1

 1

 Not required

1

 2

 Recommended

2

 1

 Recommended

2

 2

 Recommended

3

 1/2

 Recommended

2/3

Not known

Consider PEP if HIV prevalence is high in the given population

Exposure Codes

  • EC1: Mild exposure: mucous membrane/non-intact skin with small volumes/eyes or mucous membrane or subcutaneous injections following small-bore needles
  • EC2: Moderate exposure: mucous membrane/non-intact skin with large volumes or percutaneous superficial exposure with a solid needle
  • EC3: Severe exposure: percutaneous with large volume by hollow needle, deep puncture

HIV Source Codes

  • SC 1- HIV +ve, asymptomatic, CD count high, low viral load
  • SC 2- HIV +ve, symptomatic, CD count low, high viral load
  • SC unknown: HIV status unknown

Recommended PEP regimens

1) Adolescents and Adults (>10 years of age and >30 kg weight): Tenofovir 300 mg + Lamivudine 300 mg + Dolutegravir 50 mg

2) Children (>6 years of age and >20 kg weight): Zidovudine (dosage as per weight band) + Lamivudine (dosage as per weight band) + Dolutegravir 50 mg

  • PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours.
  • Duration of PEP: 28 days/4weeks

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever?

choices.text: A recent outbreak has been reported in the Indian State of Gujarat
Caused by a virus belonging to Togavirus
Domestic animals like sheep and cattle are reservoirs

questions.solution:
• Crimean–Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) virus (CCHFV) is a member of the family Bunyaviridae, genus Nairovirus.
  • Recently, few cases of Crimean Congo haemorrhagic fever have been reported from Gujarat.
  • Domestic animals like sheep, goats and cattle can develop high titres of virus in their blood, but tend not to fall ill and thus act as reservoirs of infection.

Signs & Symptoms:

  • The illness in humans is a severe form of hemorrhagic fever.
  • Typically, after a 1–3 day incubation period following a tick bite or 5–6 days after exposure to infected blood or tissues, flu-like symptoms appear.
  • The initial symptoms include mood instability, agitation, mental confusion and throat petechiae; and soon after nosebleeds, vomiting, and black stools.
  • There may be associated painful hepatomegaly, disseminated intravascular coagulation may occur, as well as acute kidney failure, shock may occur.

Management:

  • Essentially, maintenance therapies, such as hydration, blood transfusion and other specific supportive therapies (i.e., the administration of diuretics and/or antibiotics – if necessary), should be initiated as soon as possible.
  • Ribavirin is the only antiviral drug that has been used to treat CCHF.
  • Ribavirin inhibits the replication of CCHFV in vivo and in vitro.
  • However, hematological and neurological abnormalities are common side effects induced by ribavirin treatment.

questions.text: Which of the following chemical mediators of inflammation is an example of a CX3C or delta chemokine?
questions.solution:
The major role of chemokines is to act as a chemo attractant to guide the migration of inflammatory cells.

Members of the chemokine family are divided into four groups depending on the number and arrangement of Cysteine molecules.

  1. CXC chemokines (or α-chemokines): The two cysteine molecules are separated by one amino acid, represented in this name with an "X". There have been 17 different CXC chemokines described in mammals. Eg: Interleukin -8 (CXCL8).
  2. CC chemokines (or β-chemokines): They have total four cysteines of which two are adjacent cysteines (amino acids), near their amino terminus. There have been at least 27 distinct members of this subgroup reported for mammals, called CC chemokine ligands (CCL)-1 to 28; CCL10 is the same as CCL9.
  3. C chemokines (or γ chemokines): It has only two cysteines; one N-terminal cysteine and one cysteine downstream. Two chemokines have been described for this subgroup and are called XCL1 (lymphotactin-α) and XCL2 (lymphotactin-β).
  4. CX3C chemokines (or d-chemokines): They have three amino acids between the two cysteines and is termed CX3C chemokine (or d-chemokines). The only CX3C chemokine discovered to date is called fractalkine (or CX3CL1). It is both secreted and tethered to the surface of the cell that expresses it, thereby serving as both a chemoattractant and as an adhesion molecule.

The Image below shows the structure of various classes of Chemokines.

questions.text: Identify the condition caused by M. Tuberculosis as shown in the MRI Image below.
questions.solution:
The above image shows Pott disease, also known as tuberculous spondylitis, refers to vertebral body and intervertebral disc involvement with tuberculosis (TB). It depicts sagittal T1W (A) and T2W (B) images in a patient with spinal tuberculosis showing a well-defined rounded lesion (arrow) with T1 hypointensity and T2 iso-hypointensity.

The spine is the most frequent location of musculoskeletal TB, and commonly related symptoms are back pain and lower limb weakness/paraplegia.

  • The spine is involved due to hematogenous spread via the venous plexus of Batson.
  • There is usually a slow collapse of one or usually more vertebral bodies, which spreads underneath the longitudinal ligaments which results in an acute kyphotic or "gibbus" deformity. This angulation, coupled with epidural granulation tissue and bony fragments, can lead to cord compression.

Radiographic Features:

Features include irregularity of both the endplate and anterior aspect of the vertebral bodies, with bone marrow oedema and enhancement seen on MRI:

  • T1: hypointense marrow in adjacent vertebrae
  • T2: hyperintense marrow, disc, soft tissue infection
  • T1 C+ (Gd): marrow, subligamentous, disc, and dural enhancement
  • The paraspinal collections are typically well circumscribed, with fluid centres and well-defined enhancing margins.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about Trichomonas vaginalis?

choices.text: It exists in 2 forms – cyst and trophozoite form
Gold standard method for diagnosis of Trichomonas infection is – culture on CPLM or PEM
The parasite causes petechial hemorrhage giving rise to the term “strawberry cervix”

questions.solution:
• Trichomonas vaginalis is the only protozoa with one stage in its life cycle with only Trophozoite form (No cyst stage is seen).
  • It is an obligate parasite and cannot live without close association with vaginal, urethral or prostatic tissues.
  • Culture is generally done when direct microscopy is negative. It is considered Gold standard. It is grown on solid or liquid media.
  • Cysteine-peptone-liver-maltose (CPLM) medium and Plastic envelope medium (PEM) are often used.
  • Parasite causes petechial haemorrhage, termed as strawberry cervix.

questions.text: The characteristic appearance on culture as shown in the image below is caused by ______
questions.solution:
The above image shows characteristic “Pilot wheel appearance” on culture shown by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis.

  • Paracoccidioidomycosis is a chronic granulomatous disease of the skin, mucosa, lymph nodes and internal organs caused by a thermally dimorphic fungus Paracoccidioides brasiliensis.
  • In cultures at 37oC, large, oval cells with multiple buds encircling the mother cell is seen as Mariner’s or pilot’s wheel appearance.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding glanders disease except

choices.text: Strauss reaction is Diagnostic of glanders disease
Acute glanders is characterized by mucopurulent nasal discharge
Mallein Test is used for diagnosis of glanders disease
Human infection is acquired rarely from infected animals

questions.solution:
Strauss reaction is not diagnostic of glanders, as in addition to Burkholderia mallei it may also be produced by inoculation of other bacteria such as brucella species, Preisz-Nocard bacillus, actinobacillus ligniersi and B. pseudomallei.

STRAUSS REACTION: Male guinea pigs are inoculated intraperitoneally with suspected material; if the glanders organism is present, it will usually set up a necrotizing inflammation in the scrotal sac within a few days and the specific organism can be confirmed bacteriologically.

About other options:

  • Option B: Glanders disease may be acute or chronic. In acute glanders, there is fever, mucopurulent nasal discharge and severe prostration. The fatality rate is high.
  • Option C: Mallein test, is hypersensitivity test to the bacterial protein of Burkholderia mallei. Animal suffering from the glanders develop delayed hypersensitivity to the bacterial protein. This is the basis of mallein test used for diagnosis of glanders. This is analogous to the tuberculin test and may be performed by the subcutaneous, intracutaneous or conjunctival methods.
  • Option D: Human infection is occupational, found in Ostlers, grooms and veterinarians. Human infection is rarely acquired from infected animals.

questions.text: Warthin-Finkeldey cells as shown in the image below are seen in
questions.solution:
• Warthin-Finkeldey cells are multinucleate giant cells which are found in the lymphoid tissues of patients infected with measles.
  • Cytopathic effect of measles consists of multinucleate syncytium formation with numerous acidophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions.

questions.text: Which of the following media is used as transport media for Neisseria species?
questions.solution:
Stuart Transport Medium is recommended for the preservation and transportation of Neisseria species and other fastidious organisms from the clinic to laboratory.

Composition of Stuart Medium:

  • Sodium glycerophosphate
  • Sodium thioglycollate
  • Calcium chloride
  • Methylene blue
  • Agar

Characteristics of Stuart medium:

  • This medium is a chemically defined, semisolid, non-nutrient medium which prevent microbial proliferation.
  • Because of this composition the medium ensures that microorganisms present are able to survive for a sufficiently long period of time.
  • Sodium thioglycollate produces a reduced environment so as to improve the recovery of anaerobes.
  • Methylene blue acts as oxidation reduction indicator.
  • Calcium chloride maintains permeability of bacterial cells and sodium glycerophosphate maintains the pH of the medium.
  • The medium appears colourless in the reduced state and blue in the oxidized state.

Related Pearl: Organisms and their transport media

Organism Transport media
Streptococcus Pike’s media
Neisseria Stuart media
Shigella, Salmonella Cary Blair medium
Vibrio cholera

Cary Blair medium

Venkatraman–Ramakrishnan medium

Autoclaved sea water

questions.text: The Prausnitz-Kustner (P-K) reaction is an example of _________
questions.solution:
The Prausnitz–Küstner test (PK test, Prausnitz-Küstner reaction) is an immunologic test formerly used by physicians to determine if a patient has an allergic reaction to a specific antigen.

It is an example of a Type I hypersensitivity reaction.

The PK test involves transferring serum from the test subject to another healthy person. This test is not performed now and been replaced by the safer skin prick test.

questions.text: Which of the following infections gives positive Weil-Felix test with OX K agglutinins?
questions.solution:
• Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction in which the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain Non-motile Proteus strains OX 19, OX 2 and OX K.
  • Basis of the test is sharing of an alkali stable carbohydrate antigen by some rickettsiae and by some strains of Proteus vulgaris OX 19 & OX 2 and Proteus mirabilis OX K.
  • OX K is agglutinated only in Scrub typhus.

Good to know:

  • Similar antigens present on dissimilar organisms are heterophile antigens.
  • Antibodies reacting with such antigens are called heterophile antibodies.
  • Serologic tests employing these heterophile antigens are called Heterophile agglutination tests.

Inference of Agglutination pattern in Weil-Felix Reaction

Disease             OX 19 OX 2 OX K
Epidemic typhus +++ + -
Endemic typhus +++ +/- -
RMSF ++ ++ -
Scrub typhus - - +++
Rickettsial pox - - -
Trench fever - - -
Q fever - - -

questions.text: The characteristic appearance on Dienes staining as shown in the image below is caused by ______
questions.solution:
The above Image shows a ‘fried-egg’ colony (bottom) and a granular colony (top) of Mycoplasma stained by Diene’s stain.

The central dark bluish area represents the area of mycoplasmal downgrowth whereas the pale blue periphery indicates superficial growth of Mycoplasma on the agar.

Diene’s method:

  • A block of agar containing the colonies of Mycoplasma is cut and placed on a slide.
  • It is covered with a cover slip on which an alcoholic solution of methylene blue and azure has been dried.
  • The slide is observed under microscope.
  • Mycoplasma with fired egg colony morphology will stain with a dark blue center and light blue periphery and will appear highly granular. The agar background will remain clear or slightly violet.

questions.text: The chromosome involved in DiGeorge syndrome is ______
questions.solution:
DiGeorge syndrome (Thymic hypoplasia) is the most common micro deletion syndrome characterized by low copy repeats and the deletion which occurs near the middle of the chromosome 22 at a location designated as 22q11.2.

It is a developmental defect involving the endodermal derivatives of the third and fourth pharyngeal pouches.

It leads to aplasia and hypoplasia of thymus and parathyroid glands.

It is usually associated with Fallot’s tetralogy and other anomalies of heart. Neonatal tetany is also seen.

A child with DiGeorge syndrome, showing characteristic facial appearance, with tubular nose and carp-shaped (Fish-like) mouth.

questions.text: All of the following statements are false about Immunotherapy of cancer except

choices.text: Active immunotherapy was the earliest method of cancer immunotherapy
Interferons are used in the treatment of squamous and basal cell carcinomas
Dinitrochlorobenzene is used in the treatment of leukemia
Lymphokine activated killer (LAK) cells are used in the treatment of renal cell carcinomas

questions.solution:
Lymphokine activated killer (LAK) cells are used in the treatment of renal cell carcinomas.

There are different approaches in the immunotherapy of cancer which include, Passive, Active and Adoptive immunotherapy.

  • Passive immunotherapy was the earliest method of cancer immunotherapy which involved administration of the antisera, prepared by immunizing animals with tumor biopsy specimen. This method was later abandoned.
  • Active immunotherapy includes
    1. Dinitrochlorobenzene is used in the treatment of squamous and basal cell carcinomas
    2. Interferons which are used in the treatment of leukaemia, and administration of intralesional BCG in malignant melanoma
  • Lymphokine activated killer (LAK) cells obtained by treatment of natural killer cells with interleukin-2 are used in adoptive immunotherapy in the treatment of renal cell carcinomas.

questions.text: An infant had high grade fever and respiratory distress at the time of presentation to the emergency room. The sample collected for blood culture was subsequently positive showing growth of α haemolytic colony. On Gram staining these were gram positive cocci. In the screening test for identification, the suspected pathogen is likely to be susceptible to the following agent
questions.solution:
• Growth of Alpha haemolytic colonies and gram positive cocci which are isolated from a sputum of a patient with high grade fever and respiratory distress is suggestive of Pneumococcal Pneumonia.
  • Both Str. viridans and Pneumococci produce alpha hemolysis on Blood Agar.
  • Optochin (Ethyl hydrocuprein hydrochloride) sensitivity test is done to differentiate Pneumococcus from commensal like Strept Viridans.
  • When Optochin disk (6 mm, 5 µg) is applied on a plate of blood agar inoculated with pneumococci and incubated, a wide zone of inhibition occurs.

Note: Optochin Test is considered positive / sensitive when the zone of inhibition is 14 mm or greater in diameter with 6 mm disk.

  • Pneumococcus – Optochin Sensitive / Positive Optochin Test
  • Strept. Viridans – Optochin Resistant / Negative Optochin Test

The image below shows the identification chart for gram positive Cocci.

questions.text: Which of the following fungi shows germ tube formation?
questions.solution:
Germ tube formation (also known as Reynold Braude phenomenon) is seen in Candida albicans.

This phenomena is also Seen in C. tropicalis.

If a few colonies of Candida albicans are inoculated in serum, the yeast cells start to form elongations called germ tubes within 2 hours, when kept at 37°C.

It is also positive for a relatively new characterized species, Candida dubliniensis.

questions.text: The main cytokine, involved in erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) reaction is:
questions.solution:
• Elevated levels of circulating tumor necrosis factor (TNF) have been demonstrated in ENL. Thus, TNF may play a central role in the pathobiology of this syndrome.
  • Erythema nodosum leprosum (ENL) is a type 2 lepra reaction which occurs exclusively in patients near the lepromatous end of the leprosy spectrum (BL/LL).
  • The most common features of ENL are crops of painful erythematous papules that resolve spontaneously in a few days to a week but may recur.
  • However, patients may also experience symptoms of neuritis, lymphadenitis, uveitis, orchitis, and glomerulonephritis and may develop anemia, leukocytosis, and abnormal liver function tests.

questions.text: Which of the following is used to test the efficiency of sterilization in an autoclave?
questions.solution:
Bacillus stearothermophilus is used as biological sterilization indicator in the autoclave.

A biological indicator provides information on whether necessary conditions were met to kill a specified number of microorganisms for a given sterilization process, providing a level of confidence in the process.

Sterilization technique Bacteria
Hot air oven

Spores of Bacillus subtilis subsp. Niger (reclassified as B.atrophaeus)

Clostridium tetani 
Autoclave Geobacillus stearothermophilus
Filtration

Serratia marscesens

Brevundimonas diminuta
Ionizing radiation Bacillus pumilus
Ethylene oxide Bacillus globigii (reclassified as B.atrophaeus)
Plasma sterilization

Geobacillus stearothermophilus

Bacillus atrophaeus (Bacillus subtilis subsp. Niger)

questions.text: In a patient with UTI, CLED (Cystine, Lactose Electrolyte Deficient) Media is preferred over Mac Conkeys media because:

choices.text: Promotes growth of staphylococcus aureus and Candida

questions.solution:
• Both CLED and Mac Conkey media are Differential Media and they inhibit proteus swarming and both promote growth of Pseudomonas.
  • MacConkey media inhibits growth of all gram positive bacteria, and also Staphylococcus and Candida due to the incorporation of inhibitor substance Crystal violet.
  • Whereas CLED supports growth of Staphylococcus and Candida, which are also urinary pathogens.
  • Hence it is preferable to use CLED for urine samples in the laboratories.

questions.text: Innate immunity is stimulated by which part of bacteria?

choices.text: Carbohydrate sequence in the cell wall

questions.solution:
• Pathogen-associated molecular patterns, or PAMPs, are molecules associated with groups of pathogens that are recognized by cells of the innate immune system.
  • They are recognized by toll-like receptors (TLRs) and other pattern recognition receptors (PRRs).
  • Pattern recognition receptors are important component of innate immunity.
  • Toll-like receptors are e.g. of PRR Protein Family which bind to carbohydrate antigens on bacterial and viral surfaces.

The table below shows various Pattern recognition receptors and their associated Ligands.

PRR (Pattern Recognition Receptor)  Ligands
Toll-like receptors  Bacterial and viral carbohydrates
C-type Lectins  Terminal mannose & Carbohydrate on HLA molecules
Leucine-rich proteins  Lipopolysaccharide (LPS)
Scavenger receptors  Bacterial cell walls
Pentraxins- CRP, Amyloid  CRP- Phosphatidyl choline, Amyloid-Bacterial cell walls
Lipid transferases  LPS
Integrins  LPS
NOD-like Receptors  Viral DNA Bacterial muramyl dipeptide

questions.text: Which of the following microorganisms has the appearance as shown in the image below?
questions.solution:
The above image shows characteristic bipolar staining giving a “safety pin appearance” shown by Yersinia pestis.

In smears stained with Giemsa or methylene blue, Yersinia pestis shows bipolar staining with two ends densely stained and the central area clear.

 

Note:  Bipolar staining is also shown by:

  • Haemophilus ducreyi
  • Vibrio parahemolyticus
  • Calymmatobacterium granulomatis
  • Burkholderia mallei
  • Burkholderia pseudomallei

questions.text: Skeletal Muscle biopsy is used in the diagnosis of infection by ______
questions.solution:
Encysted larvae of Trichinella spiralis are present in the striated muscles of its hosts.

Adult worm is one of the smallest nematodes infecting humans.

Detection of spiral larva in muscle tissue is done by performing a muscle biopsy.

Deltoid, biceps, gastrocnemius or pectoralis muscles are usually selected for biopsy.

questions.text: Calabar swellings are seen in
questions.solution:
• Calabar swellings are seen in Loiasis.
  • Loa loa causes Loiasis. The pathogenesis depends on the migratory habit of the adult worm.
  • These wanderings through subcutaneous tissues set up a temporary foci of inflammation, which appear as swellings of up to 3 cm in size as shown in the image below called Calabar swellings or fugitive swellings because they disappear in a few days only to reappear elsewhere

questions.text: Envelope antigen (HbeAg) of hepatitis B is encoded by the _________.
questions.solution:
• HBeAg is coded by the C gene if the translation begins from the pre-C region.
  • HBV contains a small, partially double-stranded (DS), relaxed-circular DNA (rcDNA) genome that replicates by reverse transcription of an RNA intermediate, the pre- genomic RNA (pgRNA). The genome encodes four overlapping open reading frames (ORFs) that are translated into viral core protein, surface proteins, polymerase/reverse transcriptase (RT), and HBx.
  • S gene: It codes for surface antigen. It consists of:
    • S region,codes for S or major protein
    • 2 Pre-S regions, Pre-S1 codes for  L or large protein, Pre-S2 codes for M or middle protein
  • C gene:
    • When C region alone is translated: HBcAg is formed
    • When translation begins from Pre-C region, HBeAg is formed
  • P gene: Codes for DNA polymerase
  • X gene: Codes for a non-particulate protein HBxAg

questions.text:
Which of the following cell cultures are continuous cell lines:
1. HeLa
2. WI - 38
3. Hep-2
4. MRC-5
5. Mc-Coy
questions.solution:
All of the above are continuous cell lines except WI-38 and MRC-5 which are diploid human cell culture lines.

Finite vs Continuous Cell Line:

  • Normal cells usually divide only a limited number of times before losing their ability to proliferate, which is a genetically determined event known as senescence; these cell lines are known as finite.
  • However, some cell lines become immortal through a process called transformation, which can occur spontaneously or can be chemically or virally induced.  When a finite cell line undergoes transformation and acquires the ability to divide indefinitely, it becomes a continuous cell line / immortalized cell line.

Cell cultures are classified into 3 types

  1. Primary cell culture
  2. Diploid cell strains
  3. Continuous cell lines
Primary cell culture Diploid cell culture Continuous cell lines
Capable of only limited growth Cells of single type that retain original diploid chromosome Cells of single type derived from cancer cells
Cannot be maintained in serial culture Serial subcultures can be done for a limited number of times – after that, they undergo “senescence” Capable of continuous serial cultivation and can be stored in the cold (-70oC)
Used for isolation of viruses and cultivation for vaccine production Used for production of viral vaccines Used for vaccine manufacture
Ex: human embryonic kidney, human amnion, and chick embryo cell cultures.  Ex: Human fibroblast cell line for CMV,MRC-5, WI- 38 Ex: HeLa, Hep-2, KB, McCoy cell lines

questions.text: Grey or black colonies on Tellurite blood agar indicates the growth of which of the following bacteria?
questions.solution:
• The diphtheria bacilli reduce tellurite to metallic tellurium, which is incorporated in the colonies, giving them a grey or black colour.
  • The growth of diphtheria bacilli may be delayed on the tellurite medium and colonies may take two days to appear.
  • Based on the colony morphology on tellurite medium and other properties MacLeod classified diphtheria bacilli into three types, gravis intermedius and mitis.

questions.text: A 15 years old girl has received complete immunization against tetanus 7 years ago. Now she presents with a contaminated wound sustained 6 hours ago. She should now be given?

choices.text: Human tetanus immunoglobulin and single dose of toxoid

questions.solution:
The girl should be given a single dose of tetanus toxoid alone

She presented with a contaminated wound sustained 6 hours ago and she has received complete immunization against tetanus 7 years back, which comes under Category B of Tetanus Immunization.

According to the recommendations of the CDC:

Vaccination History Clean Minor Wounds All other wounds
Unknown or fewer than 3 doses Tdap/Td Tdap/TD + TIG
3 or more doses Tdap/ Td Only if > 10 years Tdap/TD Only if > 5 years

Tdap - Tetanus, Diptheria, and Pertussis

Td - Tetanus and Diptheria

Tdap for children and Td for adults but Tdap is preferred to Td for adults who have never received Tdap.

 

Categories of Tetanus immunization:

  • Category A - Taken a complete course of TT/booster within past 5 years
  • Category B - Taken a complete course of TT/booster within the past > 5 years < 10 years.
  • Category C - Taken a complete course of TT/booster within the past >10 years
  • Category D - Not taken a complete course of TT/booster or immunity status not known.

 

Note:

WHO recommends a 3-dose primary vaccination series with tetanus-diphtheria containing vaccine followed by 3 booster doses. Ideally, there should be at least 4 years between booster doses.

Related Pearl: Post exposure prophylaxis for tetanus

Prophylaxis is given based on patient category:

A. Full immunization or a booster dose within the past 5 years.

B. Full immunization or a booster dose > 5 years ago but < 10 years.

C. Full immunization or a booster dose > 10 years ago.

D. Unknown or never taken immunization

Category Clean wound Unclean wound
A Only wound care Only wound care
B Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose
C Wound care + TT single dose Wound care + TT single dose + Human tetanus immunoglobulin 
D Wound care + TT complete course Wound care + TT complete course + Human tetanus immunoglobulin

questions.text: The accepted threshold for bacteriuria to meet the definition of CAUTI is?
questions.solution:
The accepted threshold for bacteriuria for CAUTI (Catheter Associated Urinary Tract Infection) is > 103  CFU/ml while the definition for Asymptomatic bacteriuria is >105  CFU/ml.

 

Abbreviation: CFU/ml: Colony Forming Units per milliliter.

questions.text: Diene’s phenomenon as shown in the image below is exhibited by
questions.solution:
When two identical strains of Proteus are inoculated at different places on the same culture plate, the resulting swarms of growth coalesce and no line is formed between swarming culture of the same strain.

However if they are from two different strains, the spreading films of growth fail to coalesce and remain separated by a narrow but easily visible furrow.

This is known as Diene’s phenomenon.

questions.text: During community medicine postings, you are posted for the pulse polio immunization programme as an intern. You see only polio vaccine drops being administered orally to all children within the age of 0-5 years. Which of the following statements is true regarding types of vaccines against Polio?

choices.text: Salk type has the live attenuated virus
OPV can be administered in immunocompromised persons
Salk type vaccine is associated with mutations that lead to reversal of virulence
Both OPV and IPV induces humoral Ig

questions.solution:
Both OPV (Oral polio vaccine) and IPV (Inactivated polio vaccine) induce humoral IgG and IgM antibodies. OPV also induces local immunity in the lining of the intestine.

There are two types of vaccine that protect against polio: inactivated poliovirus vaccine (IPV) and oral poliovirus vaccine (OPV).

  1. OPV – Sabin:
    • OPV initially consisted of a mixture of live attenuated poliovirus strains of each of the three serotypes. OPV used in India contained, Type 1 virus 10 lakh, Type 2 virus 2 lakh and Type 3 virus 3 lakh TC ID50 per dose (0.5 ml). Trivalent vaccine has now been replaced by bivalent OPV, by removing the type 2 component from immunisation programmes (OPV switch)
    • OPV produces antibodies in the blood (humoral immunity) to all three types of poliovirus, and in the event of infection, this immunity protects the individual against polio paralysis by preventing the spread of poliovirus to the nervous system.
    • OPV strains also produce a local immune response in the lining of the intestines. The antibodies produced there inhibit the multiplication and shedding of wild (naturally occurring) virus. This is the reason why mass campaigns with OPV given simultaneously (called pulse polio immunisation) have shown to help in protecting the individual and the community, producing herd immunity.
    • A strain of poliovirus in OPV may change and revert to a form that causes paralysis, leading to vaccine derived poliomyelitis (VDPV) in humans. This may also develop the capacity for sustained circulation among the community, and is known as a circulating VDPV (cVDPV). Most of the cases of cVDPV are due to the type 2 component of OPV.
  2. IPV – Salk:
    • IPV is produced from wild-type poliovirus strains of each serotype that have been inactivated (killed) with formalin.
    • As an injectable vaccine, it can be administered alone or in combination with other vaccines (e.g., diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis, hepatitis B, and Haemophilus influenza).
    • Generally three spaced doses, 4-6 weeks apart are administered to generate adequate levels of seroconversion.

Other options:

  • Salk type vaccine contains killed inactivated virus.
  • OPV is not safe in immunodeficient or immunosuppressed subjects but the IPV is harmless.
  • Salk type is the killed formalized vaccine, hence there is no risk of mutation that can lead to a reversal of virulence like in case of OPV. 

Related Pearl: Inactivated and Live Attenuated Polio Vaccines

Characteristic

Inactivated (IPV/Salk)

Attenuated (OPV/Sabin)
Prevents disease Yes Yes
Induces humoral IgG Yes Yes
Induces intestinal sIgA No Yes
Prevents intestinal colonization No Yes
Secondary (herd) protection by spread to others No Yes
Reverts to virulence No Yes, very rarely
May cause disease in immunocompromised No Yes

Salk has K, so it is killed. 

Related Pearl: National Immunization Schedule (India)

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is / are caused by HHV8?
questions.solution:
HHV-8 or Kaposi’s sarcoma–associated herpesvirus is a known as causative agent of four diseases:

  1. Kaposi's sarcoma – an angio proliferative tumor that can involve skin (most often), lymph nodes, or viscera.
  2. KSHV associated multicentric Castleman's disease (MCD) – a B-cell lymphoproliferative disorder.
  3. Primary effusion lymphoma – KSHV-associated aggressive mature monoclonal B-cell lymphoma.
  4. KSHV inflammatory cytokine syndrome – a syndrome with MCD-like symptoms but without associated pathology.

questions.text: All of the following statements are false regarding the Milk Ring test except:

choices.text: The test is used to identify the brucella antigens present in the milk
The milk is incubated at 50°C for 10 minutes
Formation of blue ring at the top leaving behind the remaining milk unstained implies MRT negative
A concentrated suspension of killed Br. abortus stained with hematoxylin is used as antigen for the test

questions.solution:
Milk Ring Test (MRT):

  • It is used to identify antibodies present in the milk, against the Brucella antigen
  • A concentrated suspension of killed Brucella abortus stained with hematoxylin is used as antigen for the test
  • In the milk ring test, a sample of whole milk is mixed well with a drop of brucella antigen and incubated at 70°C for 40-50 minutes
  • If antibodies are present in the milk the bacilli are agglutinated and rise with the cream to form a blue ring at the top, leaving the milk unstained (MRT positive).
  • If antibodies are absent, the milk remains uniformly blue (MRT negative).

questions.text: A 45-year-old fisherman presents with pain and a lesion in his hand similar to what is shown in the image.  What is the causative organism for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a raised, well-circumscribed, violaceous lesion with the absence of pus. Thus, it is erysipeloid which is a skin infection caused by Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae.

Erysipeloid usually occurs on the fingers by direct inoculation at the site of a cut or abrasion, in people who handle animals, fish or animal products. Pain, swelling and erythema develop and the condition has been called seal finger and whale finger. Pus is usually absent at the infection site, which helps differentiate it from staphylococcal and streptococcal skin infections. It resolves without treatment in 3-4 weeks. 

Erysipelothrix rhusiopathiae is a slender, non-motile, non-sporing Gram positive bacillus. It is catalase, oxidase, and indole negative. It causes disease in multiple land animals like swine, turkeys and sheep. 

Note: Erysipelas is caused by Streptococcus pyogenes. It presents as erythematous raised lesions with sharply demarcated edges.

questions.text: Which of the following is a type III Hypersensitivity reaction?
questions.solution:
Arthus reaction is Type III (Immune complex mediated) Hypersensitivity reaction.

Arthus reaction refers to the inflammation caused by the deposition of immune complexes at a localized site.

If animals are given an antigen repeatedly until they have high levels of IgG antibody and that antigen is then injected subcutaneously or intradermally, intense edema and hemorrhage develop, reaching a peak in 3–6 hours.

Antigen, antibody, and complement are deposited in vessel walls which leads to polymorphonuclear cell infiltration and intravascular clumping of platelets.

These reactions can lead to vascular occlusion and necrosis

 

The image below shows schematic representation of a typical Type III hypersensitivity reaction.

questions.text: Beta interferon is produced by ________
questions.solution:
Beta Interferon (also known as Fibroblast interferon) is produced by fibroblasts and epithelial cells.

Interferons (IFNs) are a group of signalling proteins produced and released by host cells in response to the presence of several pathogens, such as viruses, bacteria, parasites, and also tumor cells.

Interferons are classified into three types, Alpha, beta and gamma

  • Alpha Interferon (Leukocyte interferon) is produced by leucocytes. It is a non-glycosylated protein.
  • Beta Interferon (Fibroblast interferon) is produced by fibroblasts and epithelial cells. It is a glycoprotein.
  • Gamma Interferon (Immune interferon), is produced by T-lymphocytes on stimulation by antigens or mitogens. It is a glycoprotein.
    • It is concerned with immuno-modulatory and anti-proliferative functions than with the anti-viral defence.

questions.text: Which of the following stages of Entamoeba histolytica is considered as an infective form?
questions.solution:
Mature quadrinulceate cyst passed in feces can remain viable under moist conditions for about 10 days. It is considered as an infective form.

The following are the characteristic features of various life stages of entamoeba histolytica.

Trophozoite:

  • The trophozoite is found only in tissues
  • Its cytoplasm has ground glass appearance
  • Pseudopodia are present which exhibit gliding motility
  • Nucleus has a central karyosome with radiating fibrils called linin network giving a cartwheel appearance.

Precystic stage:

  • It has a large glycogen vacuole and 2 chromatid bars
  • It secretes a refractile cyst wall to become a cyst

Cystic stage:

  • Mature cyst has 4 nuclei, no glycogen mass
  • Chromatid bars disappear

 

The image below shows various stages in the life cycle of entamoeba histolytica

questions.text: A woman presented with fever and retro-orbital pain for 2 days. NS1 antigen test was positive. Which of the following is true regarding the structure of the causative agent?
questions.solution:
A woman with fever, retro-orbital pain and positive NS1 antigen most likely has dengue fever. It is caused by dengue virus, an enveloped virus. The lipid of enveloped viruses is largely of host-cell origin, whereas protein is virus coded.

The envelope is a lipid-containing membrane that surrounds some virus particles. It is acquired during viral maturation, when the viral particle undergoes budding through the host cell membrane. Envelopes confer chemical, antigenic and biological properties to viruses. The following are the differences between enveloped and non-enveloped viruses.

Enveloped viruses Non-enveloped viruses
Ether sensitive Ether resistant
Heat labile Heat stable
Pleomorphic Non-pleomorphic
Susceptible to bile salts Resistant to bile salts

Related Pearl: Enveloped and non-enveloped viruses

  Non-enveloped viruses Enveloped viruses
DNA viruses

Parvovirus

Adenovirus

Herpes virus

Hepatitis B virus

Poxvirus
RNA viruses

Picornavirus

Astrovirus

Reovirus

Calicivirus

Hepatitis A and E virus

Hepatitis c virus

Rubella virus

Chikungunya virus

Dengue virus

Japanese encephalitis virus

Kyasanur Forest disease virus

Zika virus

questions.text: Valley fever or desert rheumatism refers to which of the following diseases?
questions.solution:
• Coccidioidomycosis commonly known as Valley fever or desert rheumatism is a mammalian fungal disease caused by Coccidioides immitis or Coccidioides posadasii.
  • C. posadasii and C. immitis are morphologically identical, but genetically and epidemiologically distinct.
  • Infections usually occur due to inhalation of the arthroconidial spores after soil disruption.

Sins & Symptoms:

  • The primary infection is most often respiratory, with symptoms resembling bronchitis or pneumonia that resolve over a matter of a few weeks.
  • The classic triad of coccidioidomycosis known as "desert rheumatism" includes the combination of fever, joint pains, and erythema nodosum.
  • Chronic fibro cavitary disease is manifested by cough, sputum, fevers, night sweats and weight loss.
  • Osteomyelitis, including involvement of the spine, and meningitis which may occur months to years after initial infection.

Coccidioidomycosis may be divided into the following types:

  1. Acute coccidioidomycosis, sometimes described in literature as primary pulmonary coccidioidomycosis
  2. Chronic coccidioidomycosis
  3. Disseminated coccidioidomycosis, which includes primary cutaneous coccidioidomycosis

Treatment:

  • Fluconazole and intravenous amphotericin B are used in progressive or disseminated disease, or in immunocompromised individuals.
  • Itraconazole or ketoconazole may be used for milder disease.
  • Fluconazole is the preferred medication for coccidioidal meningitis, due to its penetration into CSF.
  • Intrathecal or intraventricular amphotericin B therapy is used if infection persists after fluconazole treatment.
  • The antifungal medications posaconazole and voriconazole have also been used to treat coccidioidomycosis.

questions.text:
Which of the following are non-cultivable organism?
1. Rhinosporidium seeberi
2. Pneumocystis jiroveci
3. Lacazia loboi
questions.solution:
• Rhinosporidium seeberi causes rhinosporidiosis and it is not cultivable/culturable on artificial culture media.
  • Similarly Pneumocystis jiroveci cannot be cultured in artificial media.
  • Another non cultivable fungus is Lacazia loboi, the causative agent of Lobo’s disease/lobomycosis.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true regarding Non Typhoidal Salmonellosis except

choices.text: Gastroenteritis due to NTS is usually self-limited
Stool cultures remain positive for 4- 5 weeks after infection
Most common isolate from stool culture is Salmonella enteritidis
NTS can be acquired from multiple animal reservoirs

questions.solution:
• Most Common isolate of Non Typhoidal Salmonellosis NTS is Salmonella typhimurium.
  • Non typhoidal salmonellosis refers to illnesses caused by all serotypes of Salmonella except for Typhi, Paratyphi A, Paratyphi B (tartrate negative), and Paratyphi C.

About Other Options:

  • Option a: Gastroenteritis is the most common clinical presentation of non typhoidal Salmonella infection. The illness usually lasts 4–7 days, and most people recover without treatment.
  • Option b: Culturing organisms continues to be the mainstay of clinical diagnostic testing for non typhoidal Salmonella infection. Approximately 90% of isolates are obtained from routine stool culture until 4 -5 weeks after infection.
  • Option d: Transmission Occurs usually through the consumption of food or water contaminated with animal feces also transmission may occur through food products, especially eggs, poultry, under cooked ground meat. Multiple animals act as reservoir for Non typhoidal salmonellosis.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding Amsel criteria for the diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis?

choices.text: Release of fishy odour on adding 10% KOH
Epithelial cells with surface covered by adherent bacilli on microscopy

questions.solution:
The pH of vaginal fluid is >4.5 in Amsel diagnostic criteria for diagnosing Bacterial vaginosis (BV).

Bacterial vaginosis is a polymicrobial infection characterised by malodorous (Fishy smell) vaginal discharge.

In clinical practice BV can be diagnosed using the Amsel criteria:

  1. Thin, white, yellow, homogeneous discharge
  2. Clue cells (Epithelial cells with surface covered by adherent bacilli seen in stained or unstained films) on microscopy
  3. pH of vaginal fluid >4.5
  4. Release of a fishy odor on adding alkali—10% potassium hydroxide (KOH) solution.

At least three of the four criteria should be present for a confirmed diagnosis.

Note: A modification of the Amsel criteria accepts the presence of two instead of three factors and is considered equally diagnostic.

questions.text: BCYE medium is used to culture
questions.solution:
• Legionella pneumophilia has fastidious growth requirements and hence grows on complex media such as BYCE - Buffered Charcoal, Yeast extract agar with L-cysteine and antibiotic supplements.
  • It grows slowly, and the colonies may take 3-6 days to appear.

Composition of BCYE Agar and functions of each ingredient

  1. Agar
  2. ACES buffer: ACES buffer is added to maintain the proper pH for optimal growth.
  3. Yeast extract: Yeast extract supplies the protein and other nutrients necessary to support growth
  4. Charcoal: Activated charcoal decomposes hydrogen peroxide, a metabolic product toxic to Legionella species, and may also collect carbon dioxide and modify surface tension
  5. L-Cysteine: L-Cysteine is an essential amino acid, incorporated to satisfy specific nutritional requirements of Legionella species
  6. Ferric Pyrophosphate: used as an Iron supplement; iron source
  7. Ketoglutarate monopotassium salt: Alpha-ketoglutarate is added to stimulate growth

The image below shows growth of legionella on BYCE medium

Note: BYCE has also been used for the recovery of Acanthamoeba keratitis

questions.text:
Which of the following organisms are most commonly associated with Fitz-Hugh Curtis syndrome?
1. Chlamydia trachomatis
2. Escherichia coli
3. Neisseria gonorrhoea
questions.solution:
• Fitz-Hugh Curtis syndrome is a rare complication of Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID).
  • It is most commonly caused by Chlamydia trachomatis (Chlamydia) or Neisseria gonorrhoeae (Gonorrhea)
  • Occasionally other bacteria such as Bacteroides, Gardnerella, E. coli and Streptococcus have also been found to cause Fitz-Hugh-Curtis syndrome.
  • It causes liver capsule inflammation leading to the creation of adhesions.
  • The major symptom and signs include Right Upper Quadrant (RUQ) pain due to inflammation of Glisson’s capsule and perihepatic adhesions.
  • There is also tenderness on palpation of the right upper abdomen and tenderness to percussion of the lower ribs which protect the liver.
  • It is also associated with minimal pelvic pain, vaginal discharge or cervical motion tenderness.

The image below shows perihepatic adhesions in Fitz-Hugh Curtis syndrome following chlamydia infection

questions.text: The type of motility shown by vibrio cholera is
questions.solution:
• Vibrio cholera is actively motile with a polar flagellum. The motility is characteristically described as darting type.
  • The motility is very rapid and is also known as riffle bullet or shooting star motility.

Note: Darting motility is also shown by Campylobacter jejuni.

questions.text: Which of the following is a combined immunodeficiency disorder associated with both B-cell and T-cell defects?
questions.solution:
Ataxia telangiectasia is a combined immunodeficiency disorder, inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.

The disorder is characterised by cerebral ataxia, telangiectasia, ovarian dysgenesis, and chromosomal abnormalities. Telangiectasia usually appears at five or six years of age and involves the face, conjunctiva and other body parts. Death occurs due to sinopulmonary infection in early life or due to malignancy in the second or third decade.

Other options:

Option B: DiGeorge syndrome is a cellular immunodeficiency disorder associated with T-cell deficiency.

Option C: Chediak Higashi syndrome and Tuftsin deficiency are disorders of phagocytosis.

questions.text: A patient presenting with fever and acute stabbing type of chest pain is suspected to have Bornholm disease. What is the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Bornholm disease or epidemic pleurodynia is caused by Coxsackie group B viruses.

Bornholm disease is a febrile disease with sharp piercing chest pain. Onset is abrupt but sometimes can be preceded by malaise, headache, and anorexia. The chest pain may last from 2 days to 2 weeks. There might be associated abdominal pain, and this may be the chief complaint in children.

The illness is usually self-limited and recovery is complete. Relapses are common.
